channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: California coronavirus milestone: 100,000 cases. 'It hasn't ended'
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Sarah Parvini, Taryn Luna
item.description: The number of coronavirus infections in California is poised to surpass 100,000 as Gov. Gavin Newsom loosens stay-at-home restrictions.
item.content:encoded: The number of coronavirus infections in California is poised to surpass 100,000 as Gov. Gavin Newsom loosens stay-at-home restrictions.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 26, 2020: Drive-through coronavirus testing at Dodger Stadium in Elysian Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. Archdiocese could resume daily Mass, scheduled confessions next week
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: L.A. Archdiocese plans to begin gradually reopening churches, with measures to prevent crowding and physical contact, as soon as next week.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Archdiocese plans to begin gradually reopening churches, with measures to prevent crowding and physical contact, as soon as next week.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA -- APRIL 21: Francisco Lorenzo prays in front of the closed doors of the Immaculate Conception Catholic Church in downtown on Tuesday, April 21, 2020, in Los Angeles, CA. The Archdiocese of Los Angeles has announced the suspension of public Masses, at least until March 29. "I deeply regret that we are forced to temporarily suspend public celebration of the Mass in the Archdiocese of Los Angeles," Archbishop Jose H. Gomez said in a statement released March 16. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Battle between Trump and California over car pollution heads to court
item.dc:creator: Anna M. Phillips, Tony Barboza
item.description: California, joined by 22 other states, is suing the Trump administration over its decision to weaken regulations limiting auto emissions.
item.content:encoded: California, joined by 22 other states, is suing the Trump administration over its decision to weaken regulations limiting auto emissions.

media:content.media:description: Three out of every four would-be home buyers focus at least somewhat on cutting their commuting costs, according to a National Assn. of Realtors survey. Above, the 110 Freeway on a Friday afternoon.

item.title: Runyon Canyon reopens for hiking with new coronavirus safety measures in place
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Runyon Canyon reopens with limits on the number of people allowed in, a one-way hiking trail and cameras and electric counters to monitor crowds.
item.content:encoded: Runyon Canyon reopens with limits on the number of people allowed in, a one-way hiking trail and cameras and electric counters to monitor crowds.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 27: Hikers enter Runyon Canyon Park at the North entrance on Mulholland Drive in the Hollywood hills on Wednesday morning as the popular park has been reopened and is closely monitored by L.A. City person new under COVID-19 safety guidelines. Visitors are still required to wear masks at the park and people are instructed to walk in lanes with directional arrows trying to maximize social distancing. Hollywood on Wednesday, May 27, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here is what can now reopen in L.A. County, and here is what is still closed
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini, Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: Malls? Movie theaters? Hair salons? Here's a look at which L.A. County businesses can now open and which ones are still closed.
item.content:encoded: Malls? Movie theaters? Hair salons? Here's a look at which L.A. County businesses can now open and which ones are still closed.

media:content.media:description: BREA, CA - MAY 26: Shoppers walk around the Brea Mall, which reopened Tuesday, where some of the mall's stores opened their doors to shoppers as the state emerges from shutdown orders enacted to slow the spread of the coronavirus. In new guidelines released yesterday ... the re-opening of retail stores for socially distanced shopping experiences remains subject to approval from officials in each of the state's counties. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: California is reopening too quickly, posing 'very serious risk,' health officer warns
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: A key architect of the nation's first coronavirus stay-at-home order says California's fast pace of lifting restrictions "poses a very serious risk."
item.content:encoded: A key architect of the nation's first coronavirus stay-at-home order says California's fast pace of lifting restrictions "poses a very serious risk."

media:content.media:description: Santa Clara County Public Health Department Director Dr. Sara Cody speaks during a news conference in San Jose, Calif., on Friday, Feb. 28, 2020. Santa Clara County health officials confirmed a second case of unknown origin of the novel coronavirus. (Anda Chu/Bay Area News Group via AP)

item.title: Shooting leaves 5 wounded outside South L.A. apartment complex
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Five people were taken to hospitals after a shooting on Berendo Avenue near 119th Street in South Los Angeles.
item.content:encoded: Five people were taken to hospitals after a shooting on Berendo Avenue near 119th Street in South Los Angeles.

media:content.media:description: SOUTH LOS ANGELES, MAY 26, 2020 - An investigation is underway after five people were hospitalized following a shooting Tuesday night outside a South Los Angeles apartment complex. The L.A. County Fire Department said the shooting was reported near the intersection of 119th Street and Berendo Avenue in the neighborhood of Athens at about 10:40 p.m. None of the injuries are considered life-threatening

item.title: The best of the Hollywood Bowl: 24 artists on their favorite Bowl performances
item.description: For the first time in a century the Hollywood Bowl is closed for the season. Here, stars from Lionel Richie to Danny Elfman reflect on their favorite Bowl performances.
item.content:encoded: For the first time in a century the Hollywood Bowl is closed for the season. Here, stars from Lionel Richie to Danny Elfman reflect on their favorite Bowl performances.

media:content.media:description: Fireworks explode over the Hollywood Bowl on July 2, 2010.
media:content.media:credit: Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Thousands of struggling L.A. residents could get rent relief under $100-million City Council proposal
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: Renters could get funds under the plan announced by L.A. City Council President Nury Martinez.
item.content:encoded: Renters could get funds under the plan announced by L.A. City Council President Nury Martinez.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA NOVEMBER 28, 2018 --- Councilwoman Nury Martinez - Los Angeles City Council District 6. The Los Angeles City Council voted unanimously to legalize and regulate sidewalk vending, more than five years after it was first proposed by lawmakers. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Six Flags gives a preview of what it'll be like when theme parks reopen
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: Theme park reopening plans: Six Flags' safety protocols include taking temperatures and requiring people to wear masks (except while eating).
item.content:encoded: Theme park reopening plans: Six Flags' safety protocols include taking temperatures and requiring people to wear masks (except while eating).

media:content.media:description: Can anything compare to the feeling of standing upside down? Riddler's Revenge in Valencia, Calif., delivers with the biggest drop on a standing roller coaster. Experience 146 feet of thrills.

item.title: Column: Exclusive West L.A. property, surrounded by stars, on sale for $745,000. Are you dying to move in?
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Want to spend eternity with Marilyn Monroe? Or you could spend eternity next door to Don Knotts for less than a third the price.
item.content:encoded: Want to spend eternity with Marilyn Monroe? Or you could spend eternity next door to Don Knotts for less than a third the price.

media:content.media:description: Marsha Ebert regularly visits her parents' gravesites at Westwood Village Memorial Park, and knows where the celebrities are, too

item.title: A silent coronavirus threat looms large as California reopens businesses
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: At Eaton Canyon, a popular Pasadena hiking area, so many people crowded the trail Saturday morning — many without masks and jammed close together — that rangers shut it down for the rest of the month.
item.content:encoded: At Eaton Canyon, a popular Pasadena hiking area, so many people crowded the trail Saturday morning — many without masks and jammed close together — that rangers shut it down for the rest of the month.

media:content.media:description: People walk at the boardwalk in Venice Beach during the first day of the Memorial Day holiday weekend amid the novel Coronavirus, COVID-19, pandemic in California on May 23, 2020. - Los Angeles County officials announced May 22, 2020, that beach bike paths and some beach parking lots will reopen and curbside service at indoor malls will be permitted. The county reopened its beaches a week ago but kept beach parking lots, bike paths, piers and boardwalks closed. (Photo by Apu GOMES / AFP) (Photo by APU GOMES/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: California bullet train could end up needing subsidies, despite promises to voters
item.dc:creator: Ralph Vartabedian
item.description: Opponents of the state's high-speed rail project say California is preparing to violate a 2008 ballot measure promise not to use state subsidies for operation of the bullet train. Proponents disagree.
item.content:encoded: Opponents of the state's high-speed rail project say California is preparing to violate a 2008 ballot measure promise not to use state subsidies for operation of the bullet train. Proponents disagree.

media:content.media:description: Workers tie rebar on a support structure located on the South end of the Cedar Viaduct section of the California High Speed Rail Project.

item.title: One-way halls, lunch at desk, playing alone. L.A. schools could reopen with stark rules
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli
item.description: L.A. schools could reopen with stark rules: One-way halls, lunch at desk, playing alone
item.content:encoded: L.A. schools could reopen with stark rules: One-way halls, lunch at desk, playing alone

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE, CA - MAY 26: Los Angeles County Office of Education Supt. Debra Duardo tours Cerritos Elementary School in Glendale on Tuesday May 26, 2020 considering that with a persisting coronavirus threat, K-12 campuses will try to reopen in the fall. New L.A. County guidelines offer a possible roadmap but it could get complicated and costly to confront the logistics of reopening at an actual school in the wake of Covid-19. Glendale on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Glendale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Powder keg' at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison with 110 cases of COVID-19 in two weeks
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: Until May 13, none of the 2,306 men incarcerated at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison had tested positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. More than 100 inmates have been infected since.
item.content:encoded: Until May 13, none of the 2,306 men incarcerated at Chuckawalla Valley State Prison had tested positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. More than 100 inmates have been infected since.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J.   CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of racerelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Los Angeles sheriff's deputy fatally shoots man in South Los Angeles
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy fatally shot a man Tuesday evening in South Los Angeles, according to the Sheriff's Department.
item.content:encoded: A Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy fatally shot a man Tuesday evening in South Los Angeles, according to the Sheriff's Department.

item.title: L.A. County will ask state to allow restaurants, other businesses to reopen sooner
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: L.A. County supervisors say the county has made enough progress in dealing with the coronavirus that they will ask the state to allow more establishments to begin reopening.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County supervisors say the county has made enough progress in dealing with the coronavirus that they will ask the state to allow more establishments to begin reopening.

media:content.media:description: JANICE HAHN,

item.title: L.A. County allows churches, stores, pools, drive-in theaters to reopen with restrictions
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: Los Angeles County announced Tuesday that it will align with California's latest guidelines to allow faith-based services, in-store shopping at low-risk retail stores, drive-in movies and other recreational activities. Beauty salons will still be closed.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County announced Tuesday that it will align with California's latest guidelines to allow faith-based services, in-store shopping at low-risk retail stores, drive-in movies and other recreational activities. Beauty salons will still be closed.

media:content.media:description: BREA, CA - MAY 26: Shoppers come and go from the Brea Mall, which reopened Tuesday, where some of the mall's stores opened their doors to shoppers as the state emerges from shutdown orders enacted to slow the spread of the coronavirus. In new guidelines released yesterday ... the re-opening of retail stores for socially distanced shopping experiences remains subject to approval from officials in each of the state's counties. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 'What the heck is going on?' County supervisors demand answers on Vernon coronavirus outbreaks
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors on Tuesday gave local health officials and plant operators in Vernon one week to review worker safety protocols and report back.
item.content:encoded: The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors on Tuesday gave local health officials and plant operators in Vernon one week to review worker safety protocols and report back.

media:content.media:description: The City of Vernon water tower sits along the Los Angeles River. The 45-unit Vernon Villiage Park Apartments complex that is nearing completion is the first privately-owned residence the city will have in decades.

item.title: As inmate deaths and infections rise, Chino, Avenal prisons will test all employees for coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: With nine inmates at Chino prison dead after getting COVID-19, it and Avenal prison will require all staff testing.
item.content:encoded: With nine inmates at Chino prison dead after getting COVID-19, it and Avenal prison will require all staff testing.

media:content.media:description: Housing in the Elm dorm at California Institution for Men in Chino.

item.title: Orange County authorities won't enforce mask requirement: 'We are not the mask police'
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: A health order issued Friday requires Orange County residents to wear cloth face coverings when in a public setting.
item.content:encoded: A health order issued Friday requires Orange County residents to wear cloth face coverings when in a public setting.

media:content.media:description: PLACENTIA, CA - MAY 16: Jim Rafferty, owner of one of Orange County's best-known sports bars Kelly's Korner, left, chats with a regular customer on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Placentia, CA. The sports bar is effectively grounded as the pandemic shutdowns affect restaurants and limit him to take-out. Like most restaurants and bars, Kelly's has had to pivot drastically to survive. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Gimme Shelter podcast: Who should you inform if you live in an apartment complex and catch coronavirus?
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: If you live in an apartment complex and catch the coronavirus, you should inform people you've been in close contact with.
item.content:encoded: If you live in an apartment complex and catch the coronavirus, you should inform people you've been in close contact with.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 14: The Park La Brea complex, photographed on Thursday, May 14, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The Park La Brea housing complex is the largest west of the Mississippi River. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inland Empire will worship in person after state gives green light
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: In addition to dine-in restaurants and in-person shopping, Riverside and San Bernardino counties are resuming in-person worship services.
item.content:encoded: In addition to dine-in restaurants and in-person shopping, Riverside and San Bernardino counties are resuming in-person worship services.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 8, 2020: Residents who want public health orders rescinded attend an emergency meeting of the Riverside County Board of Supervisors at the County Administrative Center in the midst of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic on May 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. Type written notes are placed on chairs to keep people from sitting near each other. (Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County deems in-person church 'essential,' says rules too restrictive for megachurches
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution supporting the resumption of in-person religious assemblies starting this weekend.
item.content:encoded: The Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution supporting the resumption of in-person religious assemblies starting this weekend.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA-CA-APRIL 12, 2020: MaryAnn Lawson collects prayer requests from people gathering in their cars in a parking lot in Santa Ana to worship in an Easter service by Rev. Robert A. Schuller on Sunday, April 12, 2020. Schuller is reviving a practice that launched his father to worldwide acclaim- the drive-in ministry. For the past four years, the younger Schuller has been preaching primarily on social media, providing daily sermons from his "church with no walls." The COVID-19 outbreak - and the loss of in-person fellowship - led him back to his roots. "People need a place to go to worship on Easter, " he said. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California reopening further, but L.A. County still stymied by coronavirus numbers
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Sarah Parvini
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that barbershops and hair salons would be allowed to reopen in 47 of California's 58 counties. Los Angeles isn't one of them.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that barbershops and hair salons would be allowed to reopen in 47 of California's 58 counties. Los Angeles isn't one of them.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, MAY 6, 2020: Elaina Wilcox, owner of Color & Craft Salon is photographed inside her empty salon on Main St. in Culver City. The salon has been closed since March 19, 2020 because of the coronavirus. Wilcox , who said that her rent is $3200 a month and doesn't have an income right now, fears that she will lose her salon. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Throngs of people, many without masks, pack Venice Beach over Memorial Day weekend
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Californians cooped up for months under coronavirus stay-at-home orders crowded Southern California spots, pushing social distancing limits.
item.content:encoded: Californians cooped up for months under coronavirus stay-at-home orders crowded Southern California spots, pushing social distancing limits.

media:content.media:description: People walk at the boardwalk in Venice Beach during the first day of the Memorial Day holiday weekend amid the novel Coronavirus, COVID-19, pandemic in California on May 23, 2020. - Los Angeles County officials announced May 22, 2020, that beach bike paths and some beach parking lots will reopen and curbside service at indoor malls will be permitted. The county reopened its beaches a week ago but kept beach parking lots, bike paths, piers and boardwalks closed. (Photo by Apu GOMES / AFP) (Photo by APU GOMES/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Division scrutinized for allegedly falsifying interview cards issued the most in LAPD
item.dc:creator: Ben Poston, Leila Miller
item.description: LAPD division under scrutiny for allegedly falsifying field interview cards has played an outsized role in their production, a Times analysis found.
item.content:encoded: LAPD division under scrutiny for allegedly falsifying field interview cards has played an outsized role in their production, a Times analysis found.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 2015: Officers from the LAPD's newly expanded Metropolitan Division, stay with the driver and passenger, check them for tattoos while other officers search the vehicle in Los Angeles, Calif., on Nov. 21, 2015. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Authorities crack down on illicit Hollywood Hills parties at short-term rentals
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The L.A. city attorney and LAPD are warning homeowners they can be held accountable for renters' parties during the coronavirus restrictions.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. city attorney and LAPD are warning homeowners they can be held accountable for renters' parties during the coronavirus restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Famous Hollywood sign atop Mt. Lee.

item.title: Earthquake: 3.6 quake near El Centro, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude-3.6 earthquake was reported Tuesday at 12:53 p.m. near El Centro, Calif.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude-3.6 earthquake was reported Tuesday at 12:53 p.m. near El Centro, Calif.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Tuesday afternoon May 26, 2020, at 12:53 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from El Centro, Calif.

item.title: Hair salons, barbershops can reopen now, in Stage 3 of Newsom's plan; L.A. also loosens some restrictions
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Stephanie Lai
item.description: Gov. Newsom said California barbershops, hair salons, nail salons and other grooming services could reopen under Stage 3 of his reopening plan.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom said California barbershops, hair salons, nail salons and other grooming services could reopen under Stage 3 of his reopening plan.

media:content.media:description: ATWATER, CA - MAY 26, 2020 - - Rosa Pedraza, wearing a protective mask against COVID-19, cuts Robert Nunez' hair at Rosa Hair Salon in Atwater, California on May 26, 2020. Pedraza has owned the business for 17 years in Atwater. California Governor Gavin Newsom says California counties that have been granted regional variances allowing more types of businesses to reopen can now permit the reopening of barbershops and hair salons, with modifications such as protective gear and face coverings. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 3 Metro buses catch fire in Carson; one person injured
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: It is unclear how the three buses caught fire at a transportation hub in Carson. One person had minor injuries.
item.content:encoded: It is unclear how the three buses caught fire at a transportation hub in Carson. One person had minor injuries.

item.title: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium, where up to 6,000 people a day can be tested from their cars.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium, where up to 6,000 people a day can be tested from their cars.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 26, 2020: Drive-through coronavirus testing at Dodger Stadium in Elysian Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Eaton Canyon closed till June 1 after being overrun by visitors
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Luke Money
item.description: The Pasadena hiking spot was shut down Sunday after visitors, many not practicing social distancing due to coronavirus outbreak, crowded the trails.
item.content:encoded: The Pasadena hiking spot was shut down Sunday after visitors, many not practicing social distancing due to coronavirus outbreak, crowded the trails.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA, CA - MAY 24: Visitors stream into and out of Eaton Canyon Natural Area Park on Sunday, May 24, 2020 in Pasadena, CA during the Memorial Day weekend. Signs and park volunteers reminded visitors to wear their masks. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Coronavirus 'silent spreaders' become a bigger risk as California reopens
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: There's increasing concern that people infected with COVID-19 who show no signs of illness are playing a large role in the transmission of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: There's increasing concern that people infected with COVID-19 who show no signs of illness are playing a large role in the transmission of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 22: Hainan Airlines flight crew in full biohazard suit at Tom Bradley Terminal. Due to global pandemic and upcoming Memorial Day Weekend travelers are strongly advised to follow mask and social distancing recommendations at Los Angeles International Airport. Los Angeles Airport LAX on Friday, May 22, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Heat wave to bake parts of Southern California, dry out vegetation that can fuel fires
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in some Southern California inland areas, while the valleys will reach the 90s, according to the weather service.
item.content:encoded: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in some Southern California inland areas, while the valleys will reach the 90s, according to the weather service.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 26: Smokey Bear wears a protective face mask as he warns of High Fire Danger at the Riverside Drive and Los Feliz Blvd entrance to Griffith Park in Los Angeles Tuesday, May 26, 2020 as the Southland's latest heat wave will send the mercury soaring into triple-digit territory raising the risk of heat-related illnesses. In some locations an excessive heat warning will be in effect and temperatures are forecast to be around 20 degrees higher than normal. But even where no excessive warning has been issued ... the heat will be brutal ... especially for those working or participating in outdoor activities.... Griffith Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's battle over reopening churches isn't over despite new coronavirus rules
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin, Alex Wigglesworth, Mike Freeman
item.description: The state's plan will alter religious services in dramatic ways, and it's unlikely to end the push by some churches to allow more regular worship operations.
item.content:encoded: The state's plan will alter religious services in dramatic ways, and it's unlikely to end the push by some churches to allow more regular worship operations.

media:content.media:description: SOUTH PASADENA, CA APRIL 5, 2020: Fr Joe O'Neill gives Mass during the coronavirus pandemic Holy Family Church is closed to the public in South Pasadena, CA April 5, 2020. Normally the church would be filled with parishioners on Palm Sunday. Today the church is livestreaming their Masses. While the church remains closed they say they have more than 10,000 visitors through their our livestreamed Masses. This is the third Mass today during Palm Sunday. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Francine Orr/Francine Orr/Francine Orr/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Banks: Once homeless, a student loses 100 pounds and fends off isolation with teachers' help
item.dc:creator: Sandy Banks
item.description: A Los Angeles high school student fights cornonvirus isolation and distance learning struggles with help from his teachers.
item.content:encoded: A Los Angeles high school student fights cornonvirus isolation and distance learning struggles with help from his teachers.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 21: Keith Wallick, 17,poses for a portrait in his neighborhood South L.A. on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Wallick now lives with his older brother in an apartment in South LA . Wallick struggled in school, until he found art at Santee High School. He is now graduatin with a choice of scholarships to three different college arts programs, and has lost over 100 pounds. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite a budget crisis, L.A. officials give new bonuses to officers with college degrees
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith
item.description: LAPD officers with college degrees have begun receiving a new education bonus, even as civilian city employees are targeted for furloughs.
item.content:encoded: LAPD officers with college degrees have begun receiving a new education bonus, even as civilian city employees are targeted for furloughs.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 2019: Mayor Eric Garcetti, right, listens to LAPD Chief Michel Moore announce that for the first time in five years, violent crime was down in Los Angeles in 2018, with the number of homicides on track to be among the lowest in more than 50 years during a press conference at LAPD headquarters in Los Angeles, Calif., on Jan. 28, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Facing schedule delays, L.A. Metro seeks $120 million more for Crenshaw Line
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: L.A. County transportation officials are seeking $120 million more to complete the $2-billion Crenshaw Line, which will run from Mid-City to the South Bay.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County transportation officials are seeking $120 million more to complete the $2-billion Crenshaw Line, which will run from Mid-City to the South Bay.

media:content.media:description: Artist's rendering of the Crenshaw Line's Century/Aviation station. Officials approved another station Thursday just to the north, at Aviation Boulevard and 96th Street.

item.title: California allows many more retail stores to reopen
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin
item.description: The existing guidance for retailers now applies statewide. It marks the latest move to slowly reopen California's economy amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The existing guidance for retailers now applies statewide. It marks the latest move to slowly reopen California's economy amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Doug Jordan owner of Java Junction at The Grossmont Center, an outdoor shopping mall in La Mesa, opened his store for the first time since closing in March. The mall opened to the public today with a few gift shops, formal dress shops and a few of the small eat in dining restaurants. Late Wednesday night the State of California approved San Diego County's plan for Phase 2 of the reopening plan.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: L.A. County COVID-19 cases top 46,000 on Memorial Day
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: Los Angeles County reported 12 new coronavirus deaths and an additional 1,047 cases Monday.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 12 new coronavirus deaths and an additional 1,047 cases Monday.

media:content.media:description: Children place a flowers at the graves of fallen soldiers to pay their respects during Memorial Day observances at the Los Angeles National Cemetery to honor fallen soldiers and health care workers in Los Angeles, Monday, May 25, 2020. The annual Memorial Day commemoration at the cemetery was held without the public in attendance due to the coronavirus outbreak. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel)

item.title: On Memorial Day, Southern California honors fallen service members and those on the front line of coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Rosanna Xia, Harriet Ryan
item.description: With social distancing rules in place, Memorial Day ceremonies across Southern California were replaced by virtual gatherings.
item.content:encoded: With social distancing rules in place, Memorial Day ceremonies across Southern California were replaced by virtual gatherings.

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump salutes after placing a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery, in honor of Memorial Day, Monday, May 25, 2020, in Arlington, Va. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon)

item.title: Farmer John meatpackers demand closing of Vernon plant struck by COVID-19 outbreak
item.dc:creator: Harriet Ryan
item.description: The union representing workers at the Vernon plant that makes Dodger Dogs said the facility should be shut down pending cleaning and an investigation.
item.content:encoded: The union representing workers at the Vernon plant that makes Dodger Dogs said the facility should be shut down pending cleaning and an investigation.

media:content.media:description: VERNON, CA - NOVEMBER 3, 2017: Farmer John located at Soto St and E. 37th Street in Vernon Friday November 3, 2017 as air quality officials are expected to adopt new rules aimed at easing foul odors from animal rendering plants. Nearby Boyle Heights residents have long complained for about stomach-churning odors wafting over from five Vernon-area rendering plants, which take animal parts from slaughterhouses and cook them down into fats and proteins that are used to make pet food, fertilizer, cosmetics and products. The new standards, which took over three years for regulators to develop amid pushback from the industry, will require facilities enclose some of their outdoor animal processing operations, use odor-control equipment and take other steps to minimize offensive odors. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California limits church capacity to 25% for reopening, adds other restrictions
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin
item.description: California has released new coronavirus health guidance for religious services, limiting total attendance to 25% of a building's capacity.
item.content:encoded: California has released new coronavirus health guidance for religious services, limiting total attendance to 25% of a building's capacity.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 10: Archbishop Jose Gomez, Father Brian Nunez and Father Raymont Medina celebrate Good Friday liturgy in a nearly empty Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels to guard against the coronavirus on Friday, April 10, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 913 new COVID-19 cases and 16 additional deaths Sunday, bringing total confirmed cases to 45,034 and fatalities to 2,108.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA, CA - MAY 24: Visitors stream into and out of Eaton Canyon Natural Area Park on Sunday, May 24, 2020 in Pasadena, CA during the Memorial Day weekend. Signs and park volunteers reminded visitors to wear their masks. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: He was a Hollywood darling for fighting dog meat trade. Butchers say he staged killings; he denies it
item.dc:creator: Paul Pringle, Alene Tchekmedyian, David Pierson
item.description: Activist Marc Ching, whose work won support from Joaquin Phoenix, Matt Damon and other celebrities, denies paying butchers in Asia to harm dogs.
item.content:encoded: Activist Marc Ching, whose work won support from Joaquin Phoenix, Matt Damon and other celebrities, denies paying butchers in Asia to harm dogs.

media:content.media:description: The dogs inside the iron cage will be sold at Tomohon Market. Butchers in Indonesia and Cambodia have told The Times that Ching staged scenes by paying them to torture and kill the dogs on camera N including the one that was burned alive N in a manner far more cruel than the methods they normally employ.
media:content.media:credit: Ronny Adolof Buol/For the Times/Ronny Adolof Buol/For the Times/Ronny Adolof Buol

Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

Demonstrators gathered to protest Gov. Gavin Newson's shutdown of businesses and religious gatherings amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

Gavin Newson ordered a hard closure of Orange County beaches this weekend. But responding to public pressure in recent days, Newson has implied that a gradual reopening of beaches, parks and the economy following the coronavirus lockdown could begin as early as next week. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

media:content.media:description: Bartender Taylor Osorio wears a face mask as she pours drinks at Centro Cocina Mexicana restaurant in Sacramento, Calif., Friday, May 22, 2020. As part of Sacramento County's extended Stage 2 reopening plan, dine-in restaurants and retail stores were allowed to open at noon Friday after being closed for several months due to the coronavirus pandemic.

In California, there are more than 16,363 confirmed COVID-19 cases, according to a tally maintained by the Los Angeles Times. At least 387 have died. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mosques adapt to coronavirus shutdown by sharing the call to prayer. In Culver City, neighbors said it was too loud

item.content:encoded: Cities across Southern California have allowed mosques to broadcast the call to prayer publicly. But in Culver City, the adhan did not go unchallenged for long.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, CA - MAY 16: Mahmood Nadvi (Cq), left, standing on the rooftop, delivers Islamic call to prayers Adhan, summoning Muslims for obligatory prayers, at King Fahad Mosque in Culver City. In the midst of pandemic lockdown many mosques in Southern California got permission from local authorities to broadcast Adhan. in King Fahad Mosque on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Culver City, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

Patrons are required to wear masks. The casino reached full capacity within three hours of opening.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

The tiny city of Hawaiian Gardens hopes the new card club will bring it added revenue. (Glenn Koenig/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: First one death in the family, then another, and the toll kept mounting for Inglewood couple

Wafford, a healthcare educator at Oasis Clinic at Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital and his wife Diane Walker a retired Sheriff commander have lost relatives to COVID19 in a little more than a week. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

Yaroslavsky served on the Los Angeles City Council from 1975 to 1994 and has been active in the areas of transportation, the environment, health care and cultural affairs. item.title: Film producer charged with paying credit cards with coronavirus funds, defrauding investors
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Federal authorities arrested a Beverly Hills film producer on fraud charges after he allegedly paid off his personal credit cards with federal loans intended to help small businesses weather the coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: Federal authorities arrested a Beverly Hills film producer on fraud charges after he allegedly paid off his personal credit cards with federal loans intended to help small businesses weather the coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: Los hombres dominan abrumadoramente casi todos los sectores de Hollywood, según un estudio de USC (Mariah Tauger / para The Times).

item.title: Amid 2-day spike in coronavirus deaths, Orange County pushes for wider reopening
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The county submitted final documents Thursday night showing it has met the state's benchmarks to move deeper into Stage 2 of reopening.
item.content:encoded: The county submitted final documents Thursday night showing it has met the state's benchmarks to move deeper into Stage 2 of reopening.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE, CA - MAY 21: Signs hang at Citrus City and Smoqued California BBQ as pedestrians walk by Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Orange. Signmakers - people who paint windows, make banners or A-frames, and other such stuff - has exploded as businesses try everything to get customers during coronavirus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Corruption case against former L.A. County Assessor John Noguez tossed by appellate court
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: The former L.A. County assessor was arrested in a 2012 bribery scandal, but an appellate court tossed the long-delayed case Friday after saying prosecutors missed a deadline that was tantamount to a violation of Noguez's right to a speedy trial.
item.content:encoded: The former L.A. County assessor was arrested in a 2012 bribery scandal, but an appellate court tossed the long-delayed case Friday after saying prosecutors missed a deadline that was tantamount to a violation of Noguez's right to a speedy trial.

media:content.media:description: New charges were filed against L.A. County assessor John Noguez, one of his former top aides and a tax consultant.

item.title: Trump administration warns Garcetti against 'heavy-handed' stay-at-home orders
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith, Joseph Serna
item.description: The Trump administration sent a letter to L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti saying the Department of Justice is concerned the city may pursue "an arbitrary and heavy-handed approach" to coronavirus stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration sent a letter to L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti saying the Department of Justice is concerned the city may pursue "an arbitrary and heavy-handed approach" to coronavirus stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: In his daily COVID-19 briefing, Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti lays down plans for beginning phase two of reopening the city, what he called "baby steps forward." He detailed what businesses can reopen and issued guidelines for wearing masks while on trails or golf courses, which can reopen starting Saturday.

item.title: Newsom promises reopening plan for churches as Trump demands immediate action
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Eli Stokols
item.description: Newsom promises reopening plan for churches as Trump demands immediate action.
item.content:encoded: Newsom promises reopening plan for churches as Trump demands immediate action.

media:content.media:description: Protesters hold signs for opening churches and the state of California during the protest at Pier Plaza in Huntington Beach on Saturday.

item.title: 'They killed my dad': Glendale nursing home sued after resident contracts COVID-19 and dies
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: Family claims that Glenhaven Healthcare nursing home prohibited staff from wearing masks and gloves, leading to a deadly outbreak at the Glendale facility.
item.content:encoded: Family claims that Glenhaven Healthcare nursing home prohibited staff from wearing masks and gloves, leading to a deadly outbreak at the Glendale facility.

media:content.media:description: Undated handout photo of Ricardo Saldana, who lived in the Glenhaven nursing home in Glendale for years, visiting with his daughter, Jackie Saldana.

item.title: L.A. County reopens bike paths and beach parking lots, allows curbside service at malls
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: As Los Angeles County reopens, officials also give car parades and other drive-through celebrations the green light.
item.content:encoded: As Los Angeles County reopens, officials also give car parades and other drive-through celebrations the green light.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - MAY 12: People continue to utilize Ocean Front Walk on the beach Tuesday morning in Santa Monica as Los Angeles County Beaches will reopen tomorrow for active use only due to the coronavirus pandemic. Parking lots, piers and boardwalks will remain closed. Beach on Tuesday, May 12, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Los Angeles faces federal concern over coronavirus' spread, criticism for restrictions
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Luke Money, Noah Bierman
item.description: White House coronavirus expert Dr. Deborah Birx singled out Los Angeles as one of three regions where persistent spread remains a significant concern.
item.content:encoded: White House coronavirus expert Dr. Deborah Birx singled out Los Angeles as one of three regions where persistent spread remains a significant concern.

media:content.media:description: Dr. Deborah Birx, White House coronavirus response coordinator, speaks with reporters about the coronavirus in the James Brady Briefing Room of the White House, Friday, May 22, 2020, in Washington. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon)

item.title: Can California enjoy Memorial Day without spreading coronavirus? It will be a big test
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Colleen Shalby, Alex Wigglesworth, Luke Money
item.description: Many parks, beaches and trials will be open, but officials are urging people to keep their distance and not overcrowd these outdoor spaces.
item.content:encoded: Many parks, beaches and trials will be open, but officials are urging people to keep their distance and not overcrowd these outdoor spaces.

media:content.media:description: SEAL BEACH-CA-MAY 21, 2020: A Seal Beach Lifeguard politely reminds beach goers to keep in motion while enjoying a day at Seal Beach on Thursday, May 21, 2020, as the city of Seal Beach extends the hours they are open. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Celebrating Eid? 5 ways to safely enjoy the holiday
item.dc:creator: Sameea Kamal
item.description: Coronavirus will change the way Muslims observe the Eid holiday that marks the end of Ramadan. Here are safe ways to celebrate.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus will change the way Muslims observe the Eid holiday that marks the end of Ramadan. Here are safe ways to celebrate.

item.title: Coronavirus could force pay cuts for California lawmakers, state workers
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The budget crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak could mean pay cuts for California lawmakers and state workers.
item.content:encoded: The budget crisis caused by the coronavirus outbreak could mean pay cuts for California lawmakers and state workers.

media:content.media:description: The California Assembly casts votes on Thursday, Sept. 12, 2019 at the state Capitol in Sacramento.

item.title: Heat wave to arrive in Southern California just in time for Memorial Day
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: While coastal temperatures linger in the mid-70s, the mercury will rise significantly beginning Monday in the valleys and Inland Empire.
item.content:encoded: While coastal temperatures linger in the mid-70s, the mercury will rise significantly beginning Monday in the valleys and Inland Empire.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CALIF. - MAY 6, 2020. Jeremy Moskovitz practices physical distancing along with other visitors to Bluff Park in Long Beach, where temperatures reached into the low 90s on Wednesday, May 6, 2020. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sacramento County pulls plug on fitness studios, small gatherings after state intervenes
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: State health officials say gyms can't open and gatherings of any size are still forbidden in Sacramento County, even under relaxed restrictions.
item.content:encoded: State health officials say gyms can't open and gatherings of any size are still forbidden in Sacramento County, even under relaxed restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his plan for the gradual reopening of California businesses during a news conference at the Display California store in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, May 5, 2020. Newsom warned counties that going too far in loosening coronavirus restrictions, could endanger public health. Display California, which sells locally-made items from around the state, is planning to open for curbside service on Friday under upcoming state guidelines. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: How to celebrate Memorial Day during the pandemic
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: Memorial Day will be very different in 2020. Instead of large gatherings with friends and family, try some of these alternatives.
item.content:encoded: Memorial Day will be very different in 2020. Instead of large gatherings with friends and family, try some of these alternatives.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 04: Members of the military hold an American Flag on the field during the National Anthem before the game between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Diego Padres at Dodger Stadium on July 4, 2019 in Los Angeles, California. (Photo by Jayne Kamin-Oncea/Getty Images)

item.title: Actress Lori Loughlin and her husband enter guilty pleas in college admissions scandal
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin
item.description: After maintaining their innocence for more than a year, Lori Loughlin and Mossimo Giannulli plead guilty to fraud in the college admissions scandal.
item.content:encoded: After maintaining their innocence for more than a year, Lori Loughlin and Mossimo Giannulli plead guilty to fraud in the college admissions scandal.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 3, 2019 file photo, actress Lori Loughlin, front, and husband, clothing designer Mossimo Giannulli, left, depart federal court in Boston after facing charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. Loughlin and her husband Giannulli said in court documents Monday, April 15, 2019, that they are pleading not guilty to charges that they took part in a sweeping college admissions bribery scam. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File)
